stories.title: Wxrd, a standalone Wayland compositor for xrdesktop
Ask HN: How do you manage the “Keeping Up with the Joneses” trap?

stories.text:
Products where reviews do not matter (to me)

- Fiction books, movies, music. These are such personal taste, I mostly read reviews after I read a book or watch a film to see what other people think of the book or film. Sometimes for movies, it might be the average rating rather than the individual reviews that influences.

When reviews do matter or influence purchasing

- Non-fiction books. Although it depends on the type of non-fiction book, I generally read reviews before purchasing.

- Household appliances and electronics. If the product is a known brand, I read the reviews and assume the reviews are not fake. I purchase a product even if there are only a few reviews.

When reviews may matter

- Unbranded ('no-name') electronics or products. If it's a low-cost item e.g. a 'no-name' keyboard, then I'll probably buy the item with a quick glance at the reviews or average rating. When I buy these items it's always with a suspicion that some of the positive reviews are fake.

- Travel/Hotels: Tend to look more at rating rather than individual reviews.

---

Although the problem of fake customer reviews remains, I can't imagine purchasing a wide variety of products without reading (or watching) reviews.

When do customer reviews influence your purchases? And when do reviews not influence your purchases?
stories.title: Ask HN: Customer reviews – when do they influence you? When do they not?

stories.text:
With the year coming to an end, what's on your reading list for the year ahead that you're excited to get stuck into? Here's a few of my own to start things off -

- Finish reading "Code: The Hidden Language of Computer Hardware and Software". I'm hoping as I look to take an extended break from the 9-5 grind, I'll be able to spend more time creating some fun projects off the back of the book, cementing what is taught.

- "Project Hail Mary" by Andy Weir. After enjoyed "Martians", I'm keen to keep extending my fiction library (after largely focusing on non-fiction for the past few years).

- "Exhalation" by Ted Chiang. Last year I read "Stories of your life and others", and can see the reason behind the hype for his work (his writing style is very unique), I'd like to continue to explore more work by Ted.

- "Notes on a nervous planet" by Matt Haig. Very relatable books so far (such as "midsummer library"), I'm looking forward to continue working through his catalogue.
stories.title: Ask HN: What's on your 2022 reading list?
